content.question: The peppered moth, Biston betularia was generally white in color with black speckles. Over time a more solid black moth became the more common variety. Which of the following best explains the relationship between wing pigmentation and the coloration of a moth’s surroundings?

choices.label: The frequencies of the different phenotypes in the moth population changed randomly due to genetic drift.
If the surroundings of the peppered moth became darker, those backgrounds conferred a selective advantage to a black variety, as described by natural selection.
There was a gene flow of the black variety, spreading it throughout the moth’s normal range.
The black variety was a nineteenth century mutation, dominant to the peppered variety. The allele for the peppered trait, being recessive, decreased in frequency over time

content.answer: If the surroundings of the peppered moth became darker, those backgrounds conferred a selective advantage to a black variety, as described by natural selection.
